questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE – STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text: A patient presents with a large, deep wound and the healthcare provider decides to use a specific wound-healing procedure. What is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative pressure wound therapy

 

Negative pressure wound therapy, also known as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy, involves the application of negative pressure to a wound using a sealed dressing connected to a vacuum pump.

 

  • This therapy helps in wound healing by several mechanisms: it removes excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound, improves blood flow to the area, reduces edema (swelling), and promotes the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It is often used for large, deep wounds, chronic wounds, and complex surgical wounds to accelerate the healing process.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

VAC therapy = vacuum assisted closure therapy

 

  1. Mechanism of action: VAC therapy involves the application of negative pressure (-125 mm of hg) to a wound to promote wound healing. The negative pressure removes excess fluid and promotes the formation of granulation tissue and new blood vessels.
  2. Indications: VAC therapy is commonly used for the management of complex wounds, such as diabetic foot ulcers, pressure ulcers, and surgical wounds. It can also be used to manage wounds with high risk of infection.
  3. Procedure: VAC therapy involves placing a foam dressing over the wound and covering it with an adhesive film. A tube is then inserted through the film and connected to a vacuum pump, which applies negative pressure to the wound. The pressure can be adjusted to provide the optimal level of tension for the specific wound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured at 12 mm, and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 380, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MRCP

 

Given the patient's presentation of multiple gallstones, an enlarged bile duct diameter, and elevated liver enzymes, there is a high suspicion of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). An MRCP is the most appropriate initial investigation to visualize and confirm the presence of common bile duct stones without subjecting the patient to an invasive procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is an invasive procedure that allows both the visualization and treatment of biliary and pancreatic duct abnormalities. While it can be used to diagnose and treat choledocholithiasis, it is generally reserved for therapeutic interventions after the diagnosis has been established, given the risks associated with the procedure.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound: This technique can be very sensitive for detecting common bile duct stones and other biliary pathologies. However, in the context of a patient with an enlarged bile duct and elevated liver enzymes suggestive of choledocholithiasis, MRCP would be the preferred initial diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy: While the patient may ultimately require a cholecystectomy, especially if the gallstones are the cause of her symptoms, it's crucial to first assess and manage any potential common bile duct stones. Directly proceeding to cholecystectomy without addressing potential common bile duct stones could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, given the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggesting the presence of common bile duct stones, an MRCP is the most appropriate initial step to visualize the biliary system and confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24-h pH monitoring

 

24-hr pH monitoring is done in GERD. The above image is suggestive of gradual narrowing in lower esophagus, likely to be achalasia.

 

This is a test that measures the pH of the esophagus over a 24-hour period to assess for abnormal acid reflux. While not typically necessary for the diagnosis of achalasia cardia, 24-hour pH monitoring may be used to rule out gastroesophageal reflux disease as a potential cause of dysphagia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timed barium study: In the case of achalasia cardia, the barium will be retained in the esophagus for more than five minutes and the study may reveal a dilated esophagus with a 'bird's beak' appearance at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Endoscopy may be used to rule out other potential causes of dysphagia, such as esophageal cancer, and to obtain biopsy samples if needed.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry: This is a diagnostic test that measures the pressure and motility of the esophagus during swallowing. In the case of achalasia cardia, esophageal manometry may reveal incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. It is the test of choice for diagnosis of achalasia.

questions.text: ABCDE rule is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

 

ABCDE rule applies to malignant melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABCDE rule for the clinical evaluation of malignant melanoma:

 

A - Asymmetry: One half of the mole does not match the other half.

 

B - Border irregularity: The edges of the mole are irregular, ragged, or blurred.

 

C - Color variation: The mole has different shades of color, such as black, brown, tan, or red.

 

D - Diameter: The mole is larger than 6 millimeters or has grown in size.

 

E - Evolution: The mole has changed in size, shape, or color, or has started to bleed, itch, or crust over.

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

questions.text: Apart from the abdomen, which body part is included in e-FAST? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic cavity

 

eFAST or extended FAST covers 4 regions of abdomen (epigastrium, right and left paracolic areas and pelvis) and both the thoracic spaces.

 

Correct. The e-FAST exam extends the basic FAST exam by including views of the thoracic cavity, specifically looking for evidence of pneumothorax or hemothorax. This is done by assessing the pleural spaces on both sides of the chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retroperitoneum: These injuries are often missed on e-FAST.

 

Option B. Peripheral vessels: Peripheral vessels are not the primary focus of the e-FAST exam. The main goal of e-FAST is to rapidly identify free fluid in specific body cavities that might indicate trauma.

 

Option D. Dural and subdural spaces: These spaces are within the cranial cavity and pertain to the brain. They are not part of the e-FAST exam.

 

In summary, the e-FAST exam primarily evaluates the abdomen for evidence of trauma, but it also extends to the thoracic cavity to look for signs of pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is a bedside ultrasound examination used to evaluate trauma patients. It involves the use of a portable ultrasound machine to assess for free fluid in the abdomen, chest, and around the heart.

 

 

In addition to identifying free fluid, e-FAST can also be used to evaluate for other injuries, such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pericardial effusion. E-FAST has become a standard of care in trauma evaluation and is a valuable tool in the early detection and treatment of life-threatening injuries.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a palpable lump in her breast. Which of the following investigations cannot be used to rule out malignancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PET scan

 

In the evaluation of a breast lump or any suspicious symptoms, the triple assessment method is used. It involves clinical assessment, radiological examination, and cytological or histological examination. The combination of these three modalities has a high positive predictive value of 99.99% to exclude breast cancer.

 

Positron emission tomography (PET) scans are not typically used as part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. PET scans use a radioactive tracer to produce detailed images of the body and are more commonly used to evaluate cancers that have spread to other parts of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiological investigations: Radiological investigations such as mammography or ultrasound are commonly used as part of the triple assessment method to evaluate a breast lump. These tests help to identify any suspicious areas in the breast tissue that may require further evaluation with a biopsy.

 

Option C. Clinical examination: Clinical examination, including physical examination and assessment of medical history, is an important part of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. This can help to identify any specific risk factors for breast cancer and assess the characteristics of the lump, such as size, shape, and texture.

 

Option D. Histology and cytology: Histology and cytology are essential parts of the triple assessment method for breast cancer. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of the lump helps to establish a definitive diagnosis and determine whether the lump is benign or malignant. The sample is then examined under a microscope to determine the characteristics of the cells and provide further information about the tumor, such as the stage and grade.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: During the assessment of the breathing component of a trauma patient, which of the following is the most life-threatening injury that should be identified and managed immediately? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tension pneumothorax

 

Injuries that significantly impair ventilation in the short term, such as tension pneumothorax, must be identified during the primary survey and treated immediately.

 

It is important to note that the ABCDE protocol of trauma care should be followed, with the primary survey focusing on identifying and managing life-threatening injuries, followed by the secondary survey to identify all other injuries

 

Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, causing it to collapse. This can lead to a rapid buildup of pressure in the chest cavity, compressing the heart and great vessels, which can be life-threatening. It is crucial to identify and manage tension pneumothorax promptly by performing a needle decompression to release the trapped air.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical spine injury: While cervical spine injuries can be serious and require prompt attention, they are not primarily related to the respiratory system. They can result in neurological deficits but are not immediately life-threatening in terms of breathing.

 

Option C. Blunt cardiac injury: Blunt cardiac injury can result from chest trauma and may affect the heart's function. While it can be serious, it may not immediately impact the patient's ability to breathe. However, it requires evaluation and management.

 

Option D. Flail chest: Flail chest is no longer considered an immediate threat to life as per ATLS 2018 guidelines.

choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Uro bags - collection of urine.
  • An underwater seal bag- collection of drainage fluid from the thoracic cavity.
  • Nasogastric tube / Ryle's tube - Used for Nasogastric feeding / Stomach wash / Aspiration

choices.text: Head neck, thoracic and abdominal triage

questions.text: What are the different levels of triage in emergency care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate, delayed, and minimal triage

 

The different levels of triage in emergency care are immediate, delayed, and minimal triage.

 

Immediate triage (red tag) is the highest priority and is given to patients who have life-threatening injuries or illnesses that require prompt medical attention. Examples of immediate triage include patients with severe bleeding or difficulty breathing.

 

Delayed triage (yellow tag) is given to patients who have injuries or illnesses that are not immediately life-threatening but require medical attention. Examples of delayed triage include patients with open fractures or moderate burns.

 

Minimal triage (green tag) is given to patients who have minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention. Examples of minimal triage include patients with minor cuts or bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage helps to ensure that patients receive the appropriate level of care based on their condition and the resources available. By prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses, emergency medical personnel can provide the best possible care to the greatest number of patients in a disaster or emergency situation.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text:
A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Brodie Trendelenburg Test
  2. Morrissey's test
  3. Fegan's test
  4. Modified Perthes test
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

The Brodie Trendelenburg and Morrissey's tests aim to assess the competency of the saphenofemoral valve, while the Fegan's method is utilized to identify perforator incompetence. Meanwhile, the Modified Perthe's test serves as a diagnostic measure for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

 

1. Brodie–Trendelenburg Test:  The affected leg is raised so that the veins are emptied by gravity. Around the upper thigh region, a tourniquet is applied, sufficiently tightly to constrict the saphenous vein. The femoral vein blood flow isn’t obstructed. The patient is then asked to stand and the degree of filling of the saphenous vein is noted. On release of tourniquet, rapid filling of great saphenous vein is noted from above downwards in case of saphenofemoral junction incompetence.

 

2. Morrissey’s cough impulse test: Limb is elevated to empty the veins and then patient is asked to cough. An expansile impulse is felt on palpation at saphenofemoral junction.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Fegan's test: This is method is used to identify perforator incompetence. Site where perforators pierce deep fascia bulges on standing and depresses on lying supine, which can be felt as defects in deep fascia.

 

4. Modified Perthes test: This test is done to rule out Deep vein thrombosis. First veins are emptied and a tourniquet is placed around the thigh and then instructed to stand up. Then patient is asked to rapidly stand up and down on their toes and walk quickly for a few minutes. If filling of veins is observed, then this indicates Deep vein thrombosis. This is a painful test and is rarely used.

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain and swelling in the left side of his scrotum. The surgeon suspects testicular torsion based on the clinical presentation. Which is the most appropriate next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side

 

In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step in management for suspected testicular torsion. It involves immediate surgical exploration of both the symptomatic (painful) side and the asymptomatic (contralateral) side. Even if only one side appears to be affected, there is a risk of contralateral testicular torsion in future. This occurs as the same anatomical abnormality (high investment of tunica vaginalis/transverse testis are likely to be present on both sides.
  • The surgeon can detorse (untwist) the affected testicle and fixate it to prevent future torsion. Contralateral scrotum is explored and orchidopexy is done to prevent future risk of torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of testicular torsion: 

 

  • Timely diagnosis: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires prompt diagnosis and management to salvage the testis as the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.
  • Surgery: The definitive management of testicular torsion is surgical exploration with detorsion and fixation of the testis to prevent future torsion. The surgery should be performed within 6 hours of the onset of symptoms to maximize the chances of testicular salvage. At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed as the same anatomic defect can allow torsion on the contralateral side.

questions.text:
Mrs. Smith has been referred to the plastic surgery department for the reconstruction of a large wound on her thigh. After a thorough examination, the surgeon decides to perform a skin graft. While discussing the procedure with Mrs. Smith, the surgeon explains the difference between split skin and full-thickness skin grafts. Identify the true statement regarding split thickness and full-thickness skin grafts:(INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Primary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  2. Secondary contracture is more in split skin grafts
  3. Primary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
  4. Secondary contracture is more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Split skin grafts are partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a part of the dermis, while full-thickness grafts consist of the epidermis along with the entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Primary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to passive recoil of the elastin fibers of the dermis in full thickness grafts. Since full-thickness grafts have more dermis (implying more elastin fibers), they undergo more primary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Secondary contracture of the skin graft occurs due to the pull of myofibroblasts, and it occurs over time, when the transplanted graft starts healing. Full-thickness grafts have more ability to resist the pull of myofibroblasts, hence they have less secondary contracture than split skin grafts.

 

Primary contracture: FTSG

 

Secondary contracture: STSG

 

Thus, statements 2 and 3 are correct.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar cautery

 

The given instrument is a Bipolar cautery

 

  • Bipolar cautery, like unipolar cautery, is a form of electrosurgery used for tissue coagulation and hemostasis.
  • Unlike unipolar cautery, bipolar cautery uses two electrodes that are very close together on the surgical instrument. The electrical current flows only between these two closely spaced electrodes, which limits the current's path to a small area of tissue.
  • Bipolar cautery is often preferred in delicate surgical procedures where precise tissue coagulation is required, as it has a more localized effect compared to unipolar cautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unipolar cautery: 

 

  • Unipolar cautery is a type of electrosurgery that uses a single electrode for cutting or coagulating tissue. It is commonly used for various surgical procedures to cut or coagulate tissues, control bleeding, and achieve hemostasis.

 

 

Option C. The harmonic scalpel:

 

  • The harmonic scalpel is known for its precision and minimal thermal spread, making it suitable for various surgical procedures, including laparoscopic and open surgeries.
  • It allows surgeons to dissect tissues and achieve hemostasis with minimal damage to surrounding structures, based on generation of heat from ultrasonic waves.

 

 

Option D. LigaSure vessel sealing system:

 

  • LigaSure is known for its ability to create secure and consistent vessel seals, reducing the risk of bleeding during surgery.
  • It is a type of advanced bipolar vessel sealing device.
  • It is commonly used in a wide range of surgical specialties, including general surgery, gynecology, and urology, among others.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar cautery is ideal for controlled, precise tissue coagulation in delicate surgeries due to its localized current flow, making it more specific than unipolar cautery.

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command - 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

choices.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male individual arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident, displaying signs indicative of a potential pelvic fracture. Upon assessment, he was determined to be experiencing hypovolemic shock. What is the initial course of action for managing hemorrhage control in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

 

In the immediate aftermath of a traumatic injury where a pelvic fracture is suspected, binding the pelvis with sheets (or commercial binders, if available) is a quick and effective way to provide temporary stabilization and reduce ongoing bleeding. This technique uses the concept of tamponading or compressing the bleeding vessels within the pelvis, which can be life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate internal fixation: This involves surgical stabilization of the pelvic fracture. While internal fixation might ultimately be necessary, it's not the initial action. Operating on an unstable patient can lead to further complications.

 

Option B. Multiple blood transfusions: Transfusing blood is critical for a patient in hypovolemic shock due to bleeding. However, it addresses the consequence (loss of blood) rather than the cause (active bleeding from the fracture). Stopping or controlling the bleed is paramount.

 

Option D. Emergency external fixation: External fixators can be applied to stabilize the pelvis and control hemorrhage. While this is a more definitive action than using bedsheets, it requires more time, equipment, and a surgical setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the acute nature of the presentation and the need for immediate action to address life-threatening bleeding, the primary and fastest step would be C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis. This is a temporizing measure that can stabilize the patient until more definitive interventions (like external or internal fixation) can be safely undertaken.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4

 

The image depicts a Stage 4 pressure ulcer (bedsore), which is characterized by deep tissue loss that exposes underlying structures such as muscle, bone, or supporting tissues. Stage 4 is the most severe form of pressure ulcer, often showing significant tissue necrosis, deep crater formation, and the possibility of undermining or tunneling under the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stage 4 pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with visible muscle, bone, or supporting structures, making them the most severe and challenging to manage.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

choices.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

 

  • A family history of breast and ovarian cancer in close relatives with one of the relatives having an onset before the age of 50 years indicates a high risk for breast cancer.
  • The next step in management is genetic counselling and screening for BRA.
  • This involves discussing various genetic testing options such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.
  • Genetic testing is recommended for high-risk women with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, particularly if the diagnosis was made before age 50, if there are multiple affected family members, or if the patient has a personal history of breast or ovarian cancer.
  • Mammography is not the initial investigation of choice but can be used for surveillance after genetic screening.
  • Discontinuing oral contraceptive pills is not necessary as they do not increase the risk of breast cancer in women with a positive family history of breast cancer.

 

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, as well as her concerns about her risk, the next best step is to offer genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. These genetic mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Understanding her genetic risk can help the patient make informed decisions about her healthcare, including potential surveillance and risk-reduction strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Routine mammography: Routine mammography is a screening tool for breast cancer, but it is typically recommended for women starting at around age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines and individual risk factors. While it's an important part of breast cancer screening, it may not be the most appropriate initial step in this case, given the patient's family history and concerns.

 

Option C. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills: While hormonal factors can be associated with a slight increase in breast cancer risk, discontinuing oral contraceptive pills may not be the primary step in managing a patient with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA mutations would provide more specific information about her risk.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery: Prophylactic surgery, such as a bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy, may be considered in individuals with known BRCA mutations who have a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. However, this step would be taken after genetic counseling and testing to determine the patient's risk and suitability for such procedures. It is not the initial step in management.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

 

The image displays a Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed drainage system used in post-surgical procedures. This device comprises a flexible bulb connected to tubing, creating negative pressure to gently suction fluid from the wound or surgical site. The bulb can be compressed and then sealed to initiate suction, allowing controlled drainage and reducing the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Romovac drain: Romovac drains are commonly used after various surgical procedures, including abdominal surgeries, breast surgeries, orthopedic surgeries, and others. They are also utilized in the treatment of abscesses and some types of traumatic injuries. They are a closed drainage system.

 

 

Option C. Minivac drain – (Mini in size): A closed suction drain is placed under your skin during surgery. This drain removes any blood or other fluids that might build up in this area.

 

 

Option D. Corrugated drain: Corrugated drains are intended for open passive drainage, used in situations where wounds must be kept open. They are placed directly into the wounds left to heal by secondary intent. 

 

 

Educational Objective : 

 

The Jackson-Pratt drain is a closed drainage system that uses gentle suction to remove fluids from surgical sites, helping prevent fluid accumulation and reducing infection risk.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

questions.text: What would be the next suitable examination for a chronic smoker, aged 40, who is experiencing blue discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duplex scan

 

The duplex scan is a type of ultrasound that combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It can visualize the structure of blood vessels and the flow of blood within them. It is non-invasive, doesn't require the use of contrast media, and can provide immediate results. Given the patient's symptoms of blue discoloration of the toe (suggesting compromised blood flow) and intermittent claudication (pain in the legs while walking, indicating peripheral artery disease), a duplex scan is an excellent first choice to evaluate the patency of the arteries and the location and severity of any blockages. For a chronic smoker with these symptoms, a duplex scan is a commonly used initial diagnostic tool to evaluate peripheral arterial disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT Angiography: Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a diagnostic tool that combines X-ray technology with computer imaging to visualize blood flow in the arteries. While it can provide detailed images of blood vessels and can identify blockages or other vascular problems, it requires the injection of a contrast medium, exposes the patient to radiation, and might not be the first-line diagnostic tool in this scenario.

 

Option B. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that looks specifically at blood vessels. It provides detailed images of arteries and can be useful in detecting vascular problems. However, it might not be the first choice for initial evaluation, especially when quicker, less expensive, and equally informative tests are available, like the duplex scan.

 

Option C. Digital subtraction angiography: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive procedure that involves injecting a contrast medium into the blood vessels and taking X-ray images. It provides detailed visualization of the inner structures of blood vessels and is particularly useful for planning interventions. However, due to its invasive nature, it is typically done if planning a vascular intervention like balloon dilation or stenting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Chronic smoking can cause peripheral arterial disease, which can present with bluish discoloration of the toe and intermittent claudication.
  • Duplex Scanning is a non-invasive technique that uses ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel and can be used to investigate this condition.
  • Duplex Scanning allows for detailed visualization of blood flow within the vessel, with different colors indicating changes in direction and velocity of flow.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Colonoscopy
  2. CECT
  3. CEA
  4. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

1. Colonoscopy: This is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It provides a visual diagnosis and can offer biopsy or removal of suspected lesions. It is an essential diagnostic tool for any patient with per-rectal bleeding to identify potential sources such as polyps, tumors, or colitis.

 

2. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):  CECT can provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body. In the context of rectal bleeding, it might be used to evaluate the extent of a detected tumor, check for metastatic disease, or to view vascular anomalies that might be causing the bleeding, such as arteriovenous malformations.

 

3. CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker. Its level can be elevated in colorectal cancers as well as other malignancies and conditions. Monitoring the levels of CEA might help in diagnosing, prognosis, and checking the recurrence of colorectal cancers. 

 

Other Option:

 

4. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is another tumor marker. It is more typically associated with pancreatic cancer. However, its specificity for colorectal cancer is not as high as CEA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:

 

  • Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.

 

Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3. Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

The most probable diagnosis in this patient is periampullary carcinoma.

 

Here are the characteristic features of periampullary carcinoma:

 

  • Arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater
  • Presents with jaundice that intermittently waxes and wanes due to partial relief of obstruction to bile ducts whenever the tumor undergoes necrosis and sloughing
  • Other symptoms include weight loss, pain, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding
  • A three-phase CT scan is recommended for diagnosis- which shows double duct sign (dilated CBD and pancreatic duct).
  • Management includes resection, along with chemotherapy/chemoradiotherapy

 

Periampullary carcinoma refers to cancers that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, where the bile duct and pancreatic duct converge before entering the duodenum. These tumors can obstruct both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, leading to intermittent or waxing and waning jaundice. The anatomical location of periampullary carcinomas and double duct sign on CT makes them a likely cause in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that originates in the bile ducts. While it can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically presents with a more gradual and progressive course of symptoms. It may cause dilatation of the bile ducts, but waxing and waning jaundice is less characteristic of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Common bile duct stone: While a common bile duct stone can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically leads to a more acute presentation with sudden onset of symptoms. Waxing and waning jaundice is not a common feature of common bile duct stones.

 

Option D. Head of pancreas carcinoma: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, also known as pancreatic head carcinoma, can obstruct the common bile duct and cause jaundice. However, it tends to present with a more persistent and progressive form of jaundice rather than waxing and waning symptoms, as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

questions.text:
Match the following positions of the appendix: (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. As you prepare to suture, you recall that the angle of needle placement is crucial for optimal wound closure. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

 

This is the correct angle because inserting the needle perpendicular to the skin (at a 90-degree angle) ensures optimal tissue eversion and approximation of the wound edges. It allows for consistent depth and distance from the wound edge on both the entry and exit points of the needle, which is crucial for the interrupted suturing technique to effectively close the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To properly execute interrupted sutures, it is recommended that the needle is inserted and exited the skin at a right angle (90 degrees). It is important to rotate the needle through the tissue to prevent unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. The distance between the entry point of the suture and the edge of the wound should be nearly equal to the depth of tissue that is being sutured. Additionally, it is advised to leave a distance that is twice this measurement between two consecutive sutures.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: Before conducting an A-V fistula procedure, which of the following tests is typically conducted? The image of the test is given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allen's test

 

The given image represents Allen’s test, which indicates the patency of the radial and ulna artery in supplying the hand. Both arteries are compressed alternatively, to check if limb will survive in absence of radial artery (which will be now used in creation of AV fistula).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson's test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Patient is asked to turn his head to affected side and take a deep breath. Ipsilateral radial pulse will become weak in thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Elevated arm stress test: Elevated arm stress test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The patient is asked to abduct his shoulder and flex his forearm and open and close his fists. In presence of thoracic outlet syndrome, the affected limb will get cramps (ischemic) or paresthesia (neurogenic).

 

 

Option D. Nicoladoni's test: Nicoladoni's test is to be elicited in cases of AV fistula. There is slowing of heart rate in response to manual compression of fistula.

questions.text: Mr. Thompson, a 58-year-old male, underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for the treatment of gallstones. Following the procedure, he complained of abdominal pain and fever.
