Upon further evaluation, it was found that he had a bile leak. The surgeon ordered imaging tests to identify the extent of the bile duct injury. The imaging results showed injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak. What would be the Strasberg classification of this injury? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C

 

Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg's type C injury.

 

Correct. Strasberg Type C injuries are defined by bile leaks from the major ductal systems, such as the right posterior sectoral duct in this case. The leak can be caused by a missed stone, an unrecognized transection, or an avulsion due to excessive traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Strasberg Type A injuries are characterized by bile leaks from minor ducts or cystic duct that are present either at or near the gallbladder bed. They often present as bile collections in the gallbladder fossa.

 

Option B. Type B: Type B injuries involve an occlusion of the right posterior bile duct. This occlusion might be due to a clip placement or ligature, typically at the time of surgery. It does not involve a bile leak from an aberrant right posterior sectoral duct.

 

Option D. Type D: Type D injuries are characterized by lateral injury or partial transection of extrahepatic bile ducts/Common hepatic hepatic. This would be more extensive than just a leak from an aberrant duct.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region
Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass
Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

 

Tillaux sign is seen in presence of mesenteric cyst, which shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.

 

The Tillaux sign refers to the observation that a tumor arising from mesentry, typically a mesenteric cyst will move in a direction perpendicular to the line of mesenteric attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region: While the presence of a mass can be indicative of many conditions, the Tillaux sign specifically refers to the mobility of a mass in relation to the mesentery attachment, not merely the presence of a mass.

 

Option B. Brilliance of transillumination when a light is shone through the mass: This describes the positive transillumination test that might be observed in cystic masses like hydroceles or  superficial cysts with clear fluid like ranula.

 

Option D. Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed: This refers to a fluctuation test, where pressing on one side of a fluid-filled mass results in a palpable bulge or movement on the opposite side. This indicates the presence of fluid within the mass but isn't related to the Tillaux sign.

 

In summary, the Tillaux sign helps in the clinical assessment of abdominal masses, with the mass's mobility providing clues about its origin and location in relation to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

 

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:

 

  1. Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  2. Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  3. Zone of resonance around the lump

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

questions.text: What sign on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery in a patient who was conservatively managed in the ICU after grade 3 splenic trauma?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

The presence of pneumoperitoneum on imaging would indicate a need for laparotomy as it suggests visceral perforation, which can lead to secondary peritonitis. Conservative management is usually recommended for splenic trauma, and surgical management is reserved for cases of hemodynamic instability or failure to respond to conservative management. Splenic angiography and embolization are also used for non-surgical management. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the AST spleen injury scale, and abdominal CT with intravenous contrast is the preferred investigation. A drop of 1g% of hemoglobin may be a physiological finding, and would not warrant a surgery.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture can be managed with a urinary catheter, while distended gall bladder is a normal finding if patient has been nil per oral.

 

Grades of splenic trauma based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale:

 

 

Pneumoperitoneum, the presence of air in the abdominal cavity, is a concerning sign and typically indicates a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract or another abdominal organ. In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma, the development of pneumoperitoneum suggests a concomitant hollow viscous perforation and would likely necessitate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin falls from 11g% to 10g%: A drop in hemoglobin levels can be indicative of ongoing bleeding but may not be an immediate indication for surgery. It would typically be monitored closely, and the need for surgery would depend on the rate of decline and the overall clinical condition of the patient. Typically, a decline by >2g% Hb is suggestive of active bleed and warrants further management.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: While extraperitoneal bladder rupture is a serious condition, it is not directly related to splenic trauma. Its management involves keeping a per urethral Foleys and allowing the rupture to heal.

 

Option D. Distended Gall bladder: This is a normal physiological finding and does not mandate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is the most concerning sign in a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma and would indicate a need for surgery, as it suggests a perforation.

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

  • The preferred treatment option for a patient with an injury to the brachial artery caused by a stab injury is to repair it with a great saphenous vein graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.
  • Repairing vessel injuries requires a tension-free approach.
  • The great saphenous vein is the most desirable graft for interposition grafts because of its elastic properties, similar diameter to that of an extremity artery, lack of thrombogenicity, and long-term patency.
  • Other graft materials that can be used include the cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary arterial repair with end-to-end anastomosis is only possible if the repair can be performed in a tension-free manner. If the injured area is too long, an interposition graft is required.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when the native saphenous vein has been traumatized or when there is a size mismatch. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used as a prosthetic conduit.

 

Option D. Repair with saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used for the closure of arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Testicular mass with elevated AFP is suggestive of testicular tumor, where the next best step in management for this patient is High inguinal orchidectomy

 

This is the correct choice for the initial management of a suspected malignant testicular tumor. The inguinal approach ensures that the scrotal skin and potential lymphatic drainage are not violated. This procedure allows for both definitive diagnosis (through histopathological examination) and therapeutic management by removing the tumor. An elevated AFP further supports the possibility of a germ cell tumor, such as a yolk sac tumor or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, both of which warrant surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): While FNAC is a diagnostic procedure, it's not typically used in the primary evaluation of testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding along the needle track and is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Scrotal trucut biopsy: This is not recommended for suspected testicular tumors. Biopsying a testicular tumor through a scrotal approach can risk tumor spillage or seeding within the scrotum and can alter the lymphatic drainage pattern, thus complicating future treatment..

 

Option D. Repeat Tumor markers: While monitoring tumor markers like AFP is useful in the management and follow-up of testicular cancer, simply repeating the test without addressing the testicular mass would not be appropriate. The clinical findings and elevated AFP already provide strong evidence of malignancy, and action should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct during gestation. The rule of 2s mnemonic for Meckel's diverticulum includes 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic), located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve, approximately 2 inches in length, and with a 2% incidence.

 

Meckel's diverticulum can present with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and it can be a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception. Diagnosis is confirmed with a 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel's diverticulum, and V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is commonly performed.

choices.text: US guided pig tail catheter drainage

questions.text: A man who had undergone cholecystectomy presented five days after the surgery with abdominal pain and tachycardia. WBC count is 13000 cells/mm3. US showed fluid collection 7x7 cm in right sub-hepatic space. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) US guided pig tail catheter drainage

 

Based on the information provided, the best next step in management for a patient who has undergone cholecystectomy and presented with abdominal pain, tachycardia, and a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space, would be option B) US guided pigtail catheter drainage. Patient is likely to be suffering from post cholecystectomy acute bile duct injury.

 

This option involves the insertion of a small catheter through the skin into the fluid collection, guided by ultrasound imaging. The catheter is left in place to drain the fluid collection over several days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics and send home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space. Drainage of collection is required to control sepsis.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy and re-exploration: This is a more invasive option and is typically reserved for cases where the pigtail catheter drainage is not successful.

 

Option D. ERCP: This may be done after collection is drained, to identify the site of injury, but won’t be the next step in management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of acute bile duct injury:

 

S- Sepsis control by pigtail catheter or surgical drainage

 

N- Nutrition

 

A- Anatomical delineation via MRCP/ERCP

 

P- Planned reconstruction

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

 

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically performed as an immediate intervention for variceal bleeding. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, but variceal bleeding is primarily caused by the rupture of dilated blood vessels (varices) in the esophagus or stomach, which is related to portal hypertension.
  • Platelet transfusions are usually considered when a patient with liver cirrhosis has significant thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or when there is an underlying bleeding disorder. However, they are not the primary treatment for variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arrange PRBC (packed red blood cell) transfusion: PRBC transfusion is often necessary to replace lost blood and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. Active variceal bleeding can lead to significant blood loss, and transfusion of red blood cells is a crucial part of resuscitation.

 

Option C. IV Octreotide: IV Octreotide is commonly administered in cases of active variceal bleeding. Octreotide is a medication that helps reduce portal pressure by constricting blood vessels, including those in the varices. This can help control the bleeding until more definitive treatment, such as endoscopy or interventional radiology procedures, can be performed.

 

Option D. Urgent Endoscopy: Urgent endoscopy, typically performed within 12-24 hours, is a critical intervention in the management of variceal bleeding. During endoscopy, a gastroenterologist can identify the source of bleeding and perform interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to stop the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of variceal bleeding:

 

  • Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in laparoscopic surgery? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The Veress needle is an instrument displayed in the image that is utilized to inflate the abdomen for laparoscopic surgery. In laparoscopic procedures, there are two ways of establishing abdominal access: the direct puncture technique (closed technique) and the open technique. The Veress needle is specifically used in the direct puncture laparoscopy method.

 

Lind's Needle: Lind's needle is a type of trocar and cannula system used in medical procedures, particularly for draining fluids or inserting catheters. It consists of a sharp, pointed needle (the trocar) that is enclosed within a cannula.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digastric muscle

 

Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle.

 

  • The digastric muscle is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. This muscle is important for several functions, including swallowing and jaw movement.
  • Preservation of the digastric muscle helps maintain normal swallowing and chewing abilities, which is essential for a patient's quality of life postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of lymph nodes level 1 to 5, ipsilateral submandibular gland and tail of parotid, as well as other structures in the neck such as the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve.

 

In modified radical neck dissections, some structures may be spared, such as the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle or the spinal accessory nerve.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for a 26-year-old woman who was brought to the ER at Hospital after a car accident, with a stable blood pressure, a GCS score of 3, and a normal non-contrast CT scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

 

The patient's clinical presentation suggests the possibility of diffuse axonal injury, which occurs when the brain experiences shearing forces, often from rotational acceleration within the skull. This can result in damage to the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule, leading to disruption of axons and microvasculature.

 

 Automobile accidents are the most common cause of diffuse axonal injury, and patients often remain unconscious from the moment of impact until death. Multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution are typical of diffuse axonal injury, and CT scans may appear normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), particularly susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), is the preferred imaging modality for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury, and can reveal small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage, extradural hemorrhage, and cerebral contusion are other potential traumatic brain injuries that can present with different imaging features and may require different treatments.

 

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a type of traumatic brain injury that results from the shearing forces during rapid deceleration or rotational head trauma. It can cause profound neurological impairment, even with a seemingly normal CT scan early on. A GCS score of 3 is indicative of severe brain injury, and DAI is a common cause of such a presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Subdural hemorrhage is associated with bleeding between the brain and its outermost covering (the dura mater). While it can result from head trauma, it typically presents with altered mental status, neurological deficits, or focal symptoms. A GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Extradural hemorrhage: It can lead to rapid neurological deterioration, often with a lucid interval after the injury. A normal non-contrast CT scan is inconsistent with an acute extradural hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Cerebral contusion: Cerebral contusions are focal brain injuries characterized by bruising of the brain tissue. They can occur in head trauma and may present with neurological deficits or focal symptoms. However, a normal non-contrast CT scan would typically not rule out a cerebral contusion if it's a small or subtle contusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation with a GCS score of 3 and a normal non-contrast CT scan, the most probable diagnosis is diffuse axonal injury (option C), which can result in severe neurological impairment despite a normal initial CT scan.

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

 

  • Among the given conditions, maximum malnutrition is caused by duodenal fistulas.
  • Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified based on their location and volume of daily output.
  • Proximal fistulas have higher output and are associated with greater fluid, electrolyte, and digestive capacity loss.
  • Distal fistulas have lower output and are easier to manage, with a higher likelihood of spontaneous closure.
  • Duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 liters of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts, making them more susceptible to electrolyte imbalances than gastric fistulas.
  • The management of enterocutaneous fistulas follows the SNAP principles:
    • S: Sepsis elimination and skin protection
    • N: A period of parenteral nutrition may be required
    • A: Anatomical assessment
    • P: Definitive planned surgery.

 

A duodenal fistula involves a connection between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and an unintended location, such as the abdominal cavity. This can result in severe malnutrition because the duodenum is a critical site for nutrient absorption in the digestive process. A duodenal fistula can lead to the loss of digestive juices and nutrients, significantly impacting a patient's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatic fistula: A pancreatic fistula is a complication where pancreatic fluids leak from the surgical site. While it can lead to malnutrition due to the loss of digestive enzymes, it is not typically as severe as a duodenal fistula in causing malnutrition.

 

Option C. Distal ileal fistula: While a distal ileal fistula can disrupt nutrient absorption to some extent, it is not as critical as a duodenal fistula in terms of causing maximum malnutrition. The ileum is further down the small intestine, and its role in nutrient absorption is not as central as that of the duodenum.

 

Option D. Colonic fistula: A colonic fistula may lead to the loss of stool and fluids but is not primarily responsible for causing severe malnutrition in the same way as a duodenal fistula. The colon's main function is to absorb water and electrolytes, not nutrients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel, and after a few months, she presents with easy fatiguability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anemia. Which of the following bowel resections is least likely to cause this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

The clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency. The resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause this condition. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, and intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach is necessary for its absorption. Vitamin B12 is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia with a peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil. In contrast, the jejunum is mainly used in folic acid absorption, and the stomach and ileum are involved in the absorption of vitamin B12.

 

While the duodenum contributes to overall nutrient absorption, vitamin B12 absorption is mainly absorbed in the ileum. So, resection of the duodenum alone might not as severely impact vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Resection of the jejunum can potentially lead to malabsorption of folic acid, as this is primarily absorbed in the jejunum or ileum.

 

Option C. Ileum: The ileum is a significant site for the absorption of vitamin B12 and is also involved in folic acid absorption. Resection of the ileum can severely disrupt the absorption of these nutrients, leading to macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Stomach: The stomach is the site for production of intrinsic factor, required for B12 absorption.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in damage control surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vascular anastomosis

 

Damage control surgery (DCS) is a staged approach that involves minimal intervention to stabilize the patient and perform definitive surgery later. The focus of DCS is on hemorrhage control, resuscitation, and limiting contamination. It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage. After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving vascular anastomosis may be performed.

 

Vascular anastomosis is not typically included in damage control surgery.

 

Vascular anastomosis, is generally not performed during the initial phase of damage control surgery. Damage control surgery prioritizes addressing life-threatening injuries and stabilizing the patient. Complex procedures like vascular anastomosis are typically deferred to later, definitive surgery, after the patient's condition has been stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage control: Hemorrhage control is a critical component of damage control surgery. The primary goal of damage control surgery is to address life-threatening bleeding and stop any ongoing hemorrhage. Surgeons often use various techniques, such as packing wounds or applying temporary closures, to achieve hemorrhage control during the initial phase of damage control surgery.

 

Option B. Resuscitation: Resuscitation is a key aspect of damage control surgery. Patients who require damage control surgery are often in a state of shock due to significant blood loss and trauma. Resuscitation involves stabilizing the patient's condition by providing fluids, blood products, and other supportive measures to restore blood volume and vital organ function. It is usually done in ICU after hemorrhage is stopped.

 

Option C. Decontamination: Decontamination may be necessary in specific situations, such as chemical or biological contamination, gross spillage into peritoneum or dirty wounds.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

vascular anastomosis (option D) is not a standard part of damage control surgery, while the other options (A, B, and C) are relevant components of this surgical approach.
